legal-foundations.definition: The legal authority where your business is registered and subject to its laws
legal-foundations.example: A legal jurisdiction for a start-up is like the "home country or city" whose rules and laws the business has to follow. Learn more about Owl Explains for additional insights.

legal-foundations.definition: A legal business structure that provides limited liability protection while allowing for investment from unlimited shareholders
legal-foundations.example: Most venture-backed startups choose Delaware C-Corps for their established legal precedents and investor familiarity

legal-foundations.definition: The regulatory categorization of a digital token as either a utility (functional tool) or security (investment)
legal-foundations.example: A token that provides immediate access to platform services without promising returns is more likely to be classified as a utility

legal-foundations.definition: A four-part test used by the SEC to determine if a transaction qualifies as an investment contract (security)
legal-foundations.example: If users buy tokens primarily expecting profit from the efforts of the development team, the token likely qualifies as a security under the Howey Test (see: https://www.investopedia.com/terms/h/howey-test.asp)

legal-foundations.definition: Regulatory requirements to verify customer identities and prevent financial crimes
legal-foundations.example: Using a third-party compliance platform to automatically screen users against sanctions lists and verify their identities before allowing large transactions

security-fundamentals.definition: Controlling who has access to what resources within your organization
security-fundamentals.example: Implementing a role-based access matrix that removes all access credentials during employee offboarding

security-fundamentals.definition: The process of moving code from development to production with appropriate security controls
security-fundamentals.example: Setting up a pipeline that requires security testing and multiple approvals before code can be deployed to production

security-fundamentals.definition: A physical device that safeguards and manages digital keys and performs encryption functions
security-fundamentals.example: Using an HSM to store the private keys for your project's treasury wallet, keeping the keys offline and protected from unauthorized access

security-fundamentals.definition: Information stored directly on a blockchain, making it immutable and publicly verifiable
security-fundamentals.example: Storing NFT ownership records on-chain to ensure transparency and censorship resistance

security-fundamentals.definition: A process requiring explicit approval for accessing elevated privileges
security-fundamentals.example: Requiring multiple team members to approve access to admin functions through a time-limited permission system

business-model-canvas.definition: A strategic management template that helps founders articulate their core assumptions about target audience, value propositions, and sustainability strategies
business-model-canvas.example: A DeFi protocol using the canvas to map out how they'll provide value to liquidity providers while generating sustainable revenue

business-model-canvas.definition: An expanded view of who interacts with your product, including token holders, community members, followers, and contributors
business-model-canvas.example: A DAO considering not just active governance participants but also passive token holders as part of their customer base

business-model-canvas.definition: The methods through which Web3 projects generate and retain value, including tokenomics, treasury strategies, and yield approaches
business-model-canvas.example: A GameFi project using a combination of NFT sales, in-game currency, and revenue sharing with content creators

business-model-canvas.definition: The economic system governing a token's creation, distribution, and utility within a project's ecosystem
business-model-canvas.example: A protocol designing token incentives that reward both early adopters and long-term contributors to ensure sustainable growth

user-personas.definition: A detailed profile of your ideal user that outlines their needs, behaviors, pain points, and daily workflows
user-personas.example: A developer at a Series B startup with Solidity background who needs better tools for testing smart contracts

user-personas.definition: Potential users without existing relationships to founders who provide more honest, unbiased feedback
user-personas.example: A participant found through a Discord community rather than through personal connections

user-personas.definition: The systematic process of collecting user input, implementing changes, and showing results to encourage more feedback
user-personas.example: Tracking how many users report a specific UI issue, fixing it, and highlighting the improvement in release notes

user-personas.definition: Blockchain data that reveals user behavior patterns and can inform persona development
user-personas.example: Segmenting users by transaction frequency, wallet age, or staking behavior

grants-process.definition: Unlike VCs seeking ROI, foundation grants prioritize ecosystem impact
grants-process.example: A project creating open-source infrastructure that many can build upon

grants-process.definition: How well your project addresses a specific gap or need in the Lux ecosystem
grants-process.example: Building privacy solutions that enable real-world business transactions on Lux

grants-process.definition: Evidence that demonstrates your ability to execute and deliver on your roadmap
grants-process.example: A working prototype on Testnet testnet that shows core functionality

grants-process.definition: Applying for grants across multiple ecosystems without customization or commitment
grants-process.example: Submitting identical proposals to Lux, Solana, and Ethereum without blockchain-specific considerations

grants-process.definition: Connections and introductions provided by the foundation to help your project grow
grants-process.example: Getting introduced to institutional custodians that would be difficult to reach independently

go-to-market.definition: A detailed description of the type of company that would derive the most value from your product and provide value to your business
go-to-market.example: An identity solution startup might define their ICP as 'government agencies in developing regions seeking to implement national digital ID systems'

go-to-market.definition: A comprehensive plan that outlines how a company will reach target customers and achieve competitive advantage
go-to-market.example: A structured approach that identifies target companies, defines personas, leverages networks, and builds replicable success stories

go-to-market.definition: Using blockchain as infrastructure without being token-based, bridging traditional and Web3 technologies
go-to-market.example: A digital identity solution that uses blockchain for secure verification but interfaces with traditional systems without requiring token interactions

go-to-market.definition: Specific roles or individuals within target companies who influence or make purchasing decisions
go-to-market.example: Technical directors who evaluate blockchain integration feasibility, or CEOs concerned with regulatory compliance

go-to-market.definition: Strategic engagement with developer and user communities that influence adoption decisions
go-to-market.example: Creating educational resources for developer communities that demonstrate how your solution integrates with existing systems

sales-mastery.definition: The core emotional benefit your product provides to customers
sales-mastery.example: "We create new revenue streams" vs. "We offer a blockchain loyalty platform"

sales-mastery.definition: Detailed profile of decision-makers who will purchase your product
sales-mastery.example: CMO at mid-sized retail brand concerned with customer retention

sales-mastery.definition: Early adopter who collaborates on product development rather than expecting perfection
sales-mastery.example: A brand willing to run a 3-month pilot with weekly feedback sessions

sales-mastery.definition: Measurable outcome that demonstrates your product's value
sales-mastery.example: "15% increase in repeat purchases after implementing our loyalty program"
Introduction → Agenda → Customer pain points → Product overview → Q&A

sales-mastery.definition: Tool for tracking leads and automating follow-ups
sales-mastery.example: Using HubSpot to schedule reminder emails for prospects who haven't responded

pricing-strategies.definition: Combines a fixed subscription fee with variable usage charges
pricing-strategies.example: $1599/month base fee plus additional costs based on storage usage

pricing-strategies.definition: The direct costs associated with providing your Web3 service
pricing-strategies.example: Gas fees, validator costs, cloud infrastructure, and personnel expenses

pricing-strategies.definition: Charging clients based on their actual consumption of resources
pricing-strategies.example: Charging per transaction, API call, or data storage amount

pricing-strategies.definition: Building in margin for strategic discounts while maintaining profit expectations
pricing-strategies.example: Setting enterprise list price at $5000/month with room to offer up to 20% discount during negotiations

pricing-strategies.definition: Focusing on the business value delivered rather than unit costs
pricing-strategies.example: Highlighting $2M in potential savings rather than discussing the $50K service cost

community-building.term: Supply and Demand in Social Media
community-building.definition: Early-stage projects lack established demand and social capital
community-building.example: Instead of posting daily without purpose, focus on creating one highly valuable, educational post per week

community-building.definition: Breaking long-form content into multiple smaller formats
community-building.example: Converting a one-hour livestream into promotional clips, articles, social threads, and quote graphics

community-building.definition: Community involves active participation while audience merely observes
community-building.example: 100 active members discussing your project daily is more valuable than 10,000 silent followers

community-building.definition: Testing content ideas on a small scale before expanding
community-building.example: Lux tested a simple 'Triangle adoption' post to gauge community response before launching a full campaign

community-building.definition: A one-page document outlining an event's goals, audience, and success metrics
community-building.example: Creating a document specifying that a hackathon aims to generate 10 new project prototypes from senior developers

fundraising-fundamentals.definition: The process of moving potential investors from initial awareness to committed capital, similar to a sales pipeline
fundraising-fundamentals.example: A founder starts with 100 cold outreach emails, gets 20 intro calls, 5 follow-up discussions, and ultimately 2 term sheets

fundraising-fundamentals.definition: A centralized repository containing all due diligence materials an investor might need to evaluate your company
fundraising-fundamentals.example: A Notion-based data room containing company formation documents, financial projections, team backgrounds, and product roadmaps

fundraising-fundamentals.definition: The primary investor who typically sets the terms and often takes a board seat in a funding round
fundraising-fundamentals.example: A venture capital firm commits to 50% of your funding round and helps bring in other investors to complete the round

fundraising-fundamentals.definition: Regular communication sent to current and potential investors showing progress, metrics, and specific needs
fundraising-fundamentals.example: A monthly email highlighting 20% user growth, a key new hire, and asking for introductions to potential enterprise customers

fundraising-fundamentals.definition: The maximum company valuation at which an investor's money converts to equity in a future priced round
fundraising-fundamentals.example: An investor provides $100,000 via SAFE with a $5M valuation cap, meaning their investment will convert as if the company were worth $5M even if the actual valuation is higher

mastering-tokenomics.definition: The rules and laws that influence behaviors within a blockchain ecosystem through incentives and disincentives
mastering-tokenomics.example: A protocol offering higher APY rewards to users who stake tokens for longer periods

mastering-tokenomics.definition: All stakeholders participating in a token ecosystem, including users, validators, liquidity providers, developers, and investors
mastering-tokenomics.example: In a DeFi protocol, liquidity providers contribute assets to pools and receive token rewards in return

mastering-tokenomics.definition: The practical use cases and reasons for holding or using a token beyond speculation
mastering-tokenomics.example: Offering a 30% discount when users pay for services using the platform's native token instead of fiat currency

mastering-tokenomics.definition: Methods used to acquire initial users and liquidity for a new Web3 project
mastering-tokenomics.example: A new DEX offering higher yield farming rewards during its first three months to attract liquidity providers

mastering-tokenomics.definition: The combined value of cryptocurrency assets deposited in a DeFi protocol
mastering-tokenomics.example: A lending protocol with $100M in TVL from user deposits across multiple asset types

pitching-fundamentals.definition: The organization of visual and verbal elements in a presentation designed to secure investment
pitching-fundamentals.example: Simple slides with visual cues paired with a memorized script that tells a complete story with beginning, middle, and end

pitching-fundamentals.definition: A storytelling structure that helps organize information in a way that resonates emotionally with listeners
pitching-fundamentals.example: The Bridge Story shows how your solution connects a significant problem with an innovative solution, creating a clear path forward

pitching-fundamentals.definition: A technique for explaining technical concepts by relating them to familiar ideas or experiences
pitching-fundamentals.example: Comparing a new token incentive mechanism to how loyalty programs encourage repeat customers at coffee shops

pitching-fundamentals.definition: A three-part structure for establishing credibility as an early-stage founder
pitching-fundamentals.example: Explaining market positioning (context), user journey (content), and both short-term actions and long-term projections (climb)

pitching-fundamentals.definition: A preparation technique that helps speakers connect emotionally to their material before presenting
pitching-fundamentals.example: Identifying the key topic 'community' for a section, connecting personally by reflecting on why building community matters to you, then choosing an appropriate energy level for delivery
